description: NPR's Sacha Pfeiffer talks with Rodrigo Barquera, a researcher at the Max-Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany, about a study revealing a surprise about ancient Mayan sacrifices.
title: Researcher of ancient Mayan human remains uncovers site used in male, twin sacrifices

description: Republican lawmakers in Arizona will ask voters whether state supreme court appointments should last for life. That would include two of the justices who voted to uphold an abortion ban from 1864.
title: A ballot question could undermine efforts to remove 2 Arizona Supreme Court justices

description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy about his call to put a warning label on social media platforms. Murthy believes social media can harm teenagers' mental health.
title: U.S. surgeon general calls for tobacco-style warning labels for social media

description: Israel has announced a daily pause in combat along an aid corridor in Gaza, to increase the amount of aid getting to civilians at a critical point in the Israel-Hamas war.
title: Israel to pause fighting from morning to evening along an aid corridor into Gaza

description: Many NPR listeners responded to a story explaining why some woodpeckers hammer on metal, including a man who said it solved a 35-year mystery for him.
title: We explained why woodpeckers hammer on metal — which struck a chord with listeners

description: NPR’s Sacha Pfeiffer speaks with clinical psychologist Lisa Damour about social media’s impact on teens.
title: Is a warning label for social media enough?

description: Record-breaking heat is forecast in the Midwest through the Northeast this week. In dangerously high temperatures, we give you tips to keep safe.
title: How to keep safe as excessive heat hits the Midwest and Northeast this week

description: The Norwegian Refugee Council and UN say global migration has reached highest levels ever. One reason has to do with the way wars have changed as combatants increasingly target civilians directly.
title: Global migration spikes due to violence, climate change and economic mismanagement

description:
Israel has announced a daily pause in fighting in an effort to allow more food and other humanitarian aid into Gaza. But some are criticizing the move. We go to the border crossing.

And in London, our correspondent descends beneath the streets in search of the inspiration behind the world's most famous secret agent.
title: Is Humanitarian Aid Getting Into Gaza?; Searching for the Origins of James Bond

description: Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order pardoning more than 175,000 cannabis convictions on Monday, making Maryland the latest state to try to undo the harm imposed by criminal records.
title: Maryland is pardoning 175,000 marijuana convictions. It's part of a trend

description: For the most vulnerable in New Delhi, it's a struggle to survive. Ishtiyaq, 24, who sells the cooling yogurt drink lassi in a bazaar, says: “What can I say brother? The poor must endure it all.”
title: What it's like living through a 121 degree day

description: The new Netflix documentary Outstanding: A Comedy Revolution features interviews with dozens of gay and trans comics, archival footage and lots of jokes.
title: 'Laughter is disarming': A new documentary traces generations of LGBTQ comedy

description: The country music icon played before a crowd of 110,905 fans at Texas A&M’s Kyle Field in College Station on Saturday, according to Billboard.
title: George Strait sets a new record for the largest ticketed concert in U.S. history

description: Morning Edition wants to answer your questions on buy now, pay later payment plans.
title: We want to hear your questions on buy now, pay later payment plans.

description: Whether it's our grocery lists, travel plans or savings, most of us have felt the effects of rising prices. NPR wants to know how inflation has affected your life and answer your questions about it.
title: How have rising prices affected you? What questions do you have about inflation?

description: An NPR investigation found that 50% of U.S. military bases are in so-called "health care deserts." There weren't any surprises at last night's Tony Awards — except for the winner of Best Musical.
title: 50% of U.S. military bases face health care access issues; Tony Awards takeaways

description: In Brazil, a seven-year-old horse who survived catastrophic floods in the south of the country has become a symbol of hope.
title: Nicknamed Caramelo, a rescued horse from the flooding in Brazil, becomes famous

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to Mark Jendrysik, a professor at the University of North Dakota, about why Donald Trump may be leaning toward Gov. Doug Burgum as a potential vice presidential pick.
title: N.D. Gov. Burgum has surfaced as a top contender to be Trump’s running mate

description: Envoys and leaders of more than 90 nations participated, and most signed a statement saying Ukraine’s borders must be respected in any deal to end the war. Russia wasn't invited to the meeting.
title: World leaders met in Switzerland to discuss a roadmap to peace for Ukraine

description: Internal emails, interviews and in-app messages show Uber and Lyft deployed a powerful lobbying playbook to stop minimum wage laws in Minnesota. But drivers had a playbook of their own.
title: Uber and Lyft are fighting minimum wage laws. But in this state, the drivers won

description: An ongoing NPR investigation into military health care reveals that four out of 10 U.S. military bases are located within a federally designated health care desert.
title: 50% of U.S. military bases are in a health care desert, NPR probe finds

description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Georgetown Law professor and legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union David Cole about the Supreme Court's decision to overturn a ban on gun bump stocks.
title: U.S. Supreme Court overturns federal ban on gun bump stocks

description: The loquacious donkey in the "Shrek" franchise is actually based on a real live animal, who is now 30 years old and racking up medical bills.
title: Fans donate to the sick animal that was the model for Donkey in 'Shrek'

description: The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute report says it hasn't seen nuclear weapons playing such a prominent role in international relations since the Cold War.
title: Nuclear powers are deepening their reliance on their nukes, a watchdog group says

description: Since mid-April, heat waves have been baking in India, the world's most populous nation. The vulnerable are struggling to cope.
title: How people in India's capital city of New Delhi are coping with the heat

description: The Saudi Health Ministry said more than 2,760 pilgrims suffered from sunstroke and heat stress on Sunday alone and the number is likely to increase as Hajj ends.
title: 14 pilgrims die from sunstroke as Eid al-Adha celebrations begin for Muslims

description: Staff Sergeant Gordon Black is on trial in Russia. He was stationed in South Korea and was about to return to the U.S. when he decided without authorization to enter Russia to see his girlfriend.
title: It was another day in court for a U.S. military serviceman who faces charges in Russia

description: Bryson DeChambeau won the U.S. Open on Sunday for the second time with the best shot of his life. Meanwhile, it was another heavy dose of heartache for Rory McIlroy.
title: Bryson DeChambeau wins another U.S. Open with a clutch finish to deny Rory McIlroy
